In the engineering of pulses for various purposes (my background is MRI, but the given radar example is just as good), we define a function's "time-bandwidth product" to describe how well a function treats this version of the Fourier tradeoff. A higher time-bandwidth product function will have a larger bandwidth for a given pulse length (worse for uncertainty, which relates to how thin a slice we can image in MRI), while a lower time-bandwidth product pulse has a narrower bandwidth for a given pulse length.

Of course, the pulse/spectral energy (integrated square of the function or Fourier transform) are always equal thanks to Parseval's theorem, but if the "tails" of a given pulse's spectrum are more suppressed, we consider the bandwidth narrower. This follows the "full width, half max" definition of bandwidth.

The quantum mechanical measurements of momentum and position are each entirely statistical; both can be anything for any particular particle so it makes no sense to narrow a discussion of uncertainty to a single particle.  If we prepare a multitude of statistical particles identically, it DOES make sense to discuss the statistical distributions of their momentum and position.  In quantum mechanics we discuss the observed evolution of this prepared state while quietly acknowledging that this state only specifies the probabilities of observing a particular position and/or a particular momentum.  In quantum mechanics it is the width (sigma) of these position and momentum distribution densities that satisfy the uncertainty (or unsharpness) principle.

The simplest way of thinking about it I think, is considering a straight beam of light. There are limits to the possible solutions to an electromagnetic wave in free space, and you can't just have a completely unidirectional beam. Because that violates what would be a valid solution to a wave equation like Maxwell's equations. So a laser pointer beam, that's very columnated, but that's only possible because its width is much larger than a wavelength of the light it carries. There is no valid solution to Maxwell's equations that involves even a moderately straight beam of light with a width of the beam of 1 wavelength. If the width of the beam is that small, it will immediately start spreading out in all directions. Thus it is only because a laser pointer beam is many thousands of wavelengths in width, that it is possible for a moderately straight beam. But this means that the wider the beam gets, the more columnated the beam can theoretically be made. If you wanted to shine a laser to the moon and not have it diverge to be a mile wide on the moon's surface when it gets there, a laser pointer won't do.... oddly enough, if you give up having it be a very narrow beam in the first place, that makes it possible to make it narrower when it actually gets there. So a beam that is 1 wavelength in width must spread out in an angle thereabouts of a radian, but a beam that is 10/(2*pi) thousand wavelengths in width, can spread out in an angle that is thereabouts of 1/10000 of a radian. Which means a 632 nm wavelength red laser beam that starts out 632 micrometers in width at the beginning, 2/3 of a millimeter, and 1000 wavelengths, can't be columnated better than a divergence of about 1/6283 radian, so after traveling for 1 kilometer, it will be 16 cm in width...... but if it starts out 6.32 millimeters in width at the beginning, the theoretical minimum divergence after traveling 1 km will be 1/10 as much, so it can spread out from .63 cm to just 2.2 cm, and the narrowest beam it can be after traveling 1 km will be possible if it starts with a width of just a bit more than that.... but that will be optimal for traveling 1 km.... after traveling 400 thousand km to the moon, it will be 6.4 km wide. So you would want it 6.3 meters in width, and then after traveling 400 thousand km, it would be possible for it to be much straighter and only spread out from 6.3 meters to twice that by the time it gets to the moon.


But what does this have to do with the heisenberg uncertainty principle? Well the wave nature of light, it having to satisfy maxwell's equations, places limits on how straight a beam can be given how many wavelengths wide the beam is..... but the individual photons themselves, have momentums. And where in the beam is any given photon, is more uncertain if it is a 6.3 meter wide beam, than if it is a .63 cm wide beam, which allows for its forward momentum to be more certain, in other words for it to be more precisely moving forward and not to the side, and remain columnated. And there you have the 2 parts of the heisenberg uncertainty principle, momentum and position. The wider the beam is, the more uncertain the position of a single photon can be within the beam, and therefore the straighter it is possible for it to be, the less the beam spreads out further with distance.... but constrain the beam to be a narrow beam to begin with, and that makes its momentum more uncertain, and it can't help but spread out more as it travels.

Moreover, in linear algebra terms, this relates to how that coordinates change when you rotate from one basis to another and that such a basis rotation causes a vector which lies on an axis to no longer do so. A Dirac delta or close to one - ideally localized particle - is a "vector" lying along a single "axis" of the infinite-dimensional vector space, where the "axes" (not the vectors!) represent possible positions in (real, not vector) space. When you rotate basis to the momentum basis, that is, to sine waves, then now this vector no longer lies along an axis and thus has components along many axes - many possible points in momentum, so it appears spread out when you graph the associated wave function you get something much more spread out. And it's not hard to become tempted to make the jump that given that the evolution of such a dense wave packet is to spread out, that it could be described by itself a progressive rotation (or more complicated motion) of the basis vectors. And you can indeed do that. That is the "Heisenberg picture" of quantum mechanics. The other picture with the wave function in single basis spreading - i.e. the "usual" picture and which corresponds to the vector wandering - is the "Schrodinger picture" of quantum mechanics.

We can actually see this uncertainty principle in a simpler scenario without waves. Simply consider some moving object, say a car, which you measure over some distance it moves. If you measure it for a short time, you will see that it occupied a small interval of positions, so you have a good idea of where the car was at that time. However, you can't really tell how fast the car was going because it was measured over such a small time period that any fluctuations from the average speed are exaggerated over the entire interval. So, you could see a measurement of 40 mph when the car is actually going 60 mph on average. The opposite happens when you take a longer recording; the length of the interval of positions will be quite large, so it would be hard to say where it was during that time, but the velocity measured over the interval would be very close to the true average velocity of the vehicle. The real relationship here is that we need a lot of time to be able to tell the velocity but we need a short amount of time to tell the position.

Conservation of momentum is deeply related to the symmetry of translation.
Translation: If we move our coordinate axis in the Universe by 1 unit in any direction, all the physics should be the same, even if we label the directions differently.
Momentum: If an object moves by 1 unit in some direction over 1 unit of time, in the next unit of time, it should also move by 1 unit in the same direction, since the object sees itself in a Universe which has been translated, and its physics should stay the same. (this is just how I picture it, the rigor is Noether's Theorem)

Taking this as granted, it turns out that it leads to momentum being related to a space derivative or spatial frequency, things changing in space (translation) but the momentum stays the same (conservation). In a similar sense, frequency is related to time derivatives. "sin(frequency*t)" has derivative "frequency * cos(frequency*t)", and second derivative "-frequency^2 * sin(frequency*t)". The time derivatives take the frequency out of sines and cosines and give you back the original function (wow, eigenfunctions!), but you could also take the derivative with respect to frequency and get the time instead. The derivative of one gives you the value of the other (wow, eigenvalues!). And given a function of (frequency*t), you can take derivatives, integrals, Fourier transforms, etc. with respect to either frequency or time. Since the two appear together as a product, math lets you do either.

This is the connection that simultaneously connects momentum to wavelength in the de Broglie picture where waves are sin(2*pi*x/wavelength) or sin(momentum * x * stuff), and provides the basis for why frequency-time are Fourier pairs for time-series, space-momentum are Fourier pairs for wavefunctions/matter waves, Energy-time are Fourier pairs (example: particle anti-particle pairs that "borrow energy" last for small amounts of time, but energetically stable particles last a long time)

Short version: Notice that a wave has a wavelength, and that wavelength is conserved, and the wavelength tells you something about how the wave changes over position. Notice that a particle has a momentum, and that momentum is conserved, and the momentum tells you something about how the particle changes position. From the similarities, assume wavelength must be related somehow to momentum.

It should be noted that the uncertainty principle in modern formulations of quantum mechanics doesn't rely on fourier transform pairs at all. It is instead simply a consequence of non commuting observables and the postulate that single measurements only yield probabilistic outcomes that obey the probability distribution related to the quantum state. In conventional quantum mechanics all observables like position and momentum are represented by complex linear operators (i.e. matrices in most practical cases) with real eigenvalues. So if you're familiar with the linear algebra series of this channel then non-commuting observables can be thought of as pairs of matrices A, B where the product AB is not equal to BA, usually represented as the commutator [A, B] = AB - BA being different to 0. For position x and momentum p the commutator is [x, p] = ih/(2π) for example, with Planck's constant h. The fourier transform in the uncertainty principle then appears as a consequence of this commutation relation.

Another lovely video, but there are some points that need to be made re: the uncertainty principle. Firstly, yes, the unsharpness relation is a far better term for it and the layman understanding is way off. It makes far more sense to consider the relation as a trade-off that is inherent to the fact not all observable quantities can be measured jointly.
The version of the relation that you described would best be considered a 'preparation uncertainty relation' (PUR) in the sense that a state cannot be sufficiently localised for two incompatible observables (that is, ones that cannot be jointly measured). Hence, by comparing the standard deviations of the ideal measurements of these two observables on systems prepared in this state would have a product (or sum, depending on your preferred form) that fits a Heisenberg-like PUR. (Note that each of these systems would only have one of these measurements performed on them, as the resulting measurement would result in a collapse of the state and so subsequent measurements would lose any context to what has happened beforehand.)
However, there exist other forms of uncertainty/unsharpness relations that describe the situation of either a joint or sequential measurement scheme (technically also a joint measurement but most people won't have read this far anyway and I don't want to further exclude readers); in these relations we are having to see what compromises (i.e., to the sharpness of the observables) must be made in order for us to measure two incompatible observables such that we can deduce some information about both of them. In some cases this can be linked back to the PUR for these observables (assuming an appropriate measure of error, which is not so obvious in these circumstances), but that is not always the case, nor should we expect it to be.
Finally, I'd mention that this tie is of course due to the fact that position and momentum form a canonically conjugate pair of observables, so one is the generator of evolution of the other. In such cases we do find a link to their mutual Fourier transforms and yes this reasoning can be made with regards to their ideal (or discretised) measurements. However, this is no longer true when one starts to consider additional observables, which are not Fourier transforms of one another. (A quick technical argument would come from considering a 2-level quantum system, where each ideal measurement can be described as a unit vector on a 3-dimensional real sphere, known as the Bloch sphere; any such pair of vectors that are not antipodal are incompatible but will in general not be related via discrete Fourier transforms.) These cases far outweigh those in which the above arguments can be made, though I concede that they would not have been at the forefront of Heisenberg and de Broglie's minds at the time.

As I said before, another lovely video, but I felt some clarity may have been needed, as the uncertainty relations are ultimately a non-classical aspect of the theory (and of general probabilistic theories too).

As a physicist, I just want to point out something that usually bothers me about some phrasings of the uncertainty principle (which you were careful to also do in the last minutes of the video). When people say "you can't know the position and momentum of a particle", you really need to bring the probabilistic interpretation of quantum mechanics to make sense of that. It certainly does not mean that you can't measure both quantities. If you have a certain localized quantum state (with low position uncertainty) and measure its momentum, you will get a definite result in your detector. It is only when you prepare the same localized state and measure its momentum again that you realize the result is now different than before (and repeating this process many many times you'll conclude indeed that the uncertainty of the momentum is large). This has to do with particles in quantum mechanics not being described by its classical state (which is characterized entirely by its position and momentum) but by its wave function. That popular phrasing of the uncertainty principle in a way extrapolates by saying that the particle "has" a position or momentum a priori, which is a little misleading (or at least debatable in the various interpretations of quantum mechanics).
